head.title: Rational Tuning of Ultramicropore Dimensions in MOF-74 for Size-Selective Separation of Light Hydrocarbons | Chemistry of Materials

meta.content: Rational Tuning of Ultramicropore Dimensions in MOF-74 for Size-Selective Separation of Light Hydrocarbons

The separation of light hydrocarbon mixtures is one of the most important yet energy-intensive processes in the petrochemical industry. Solid adsorbent materials could potentially not only lower energy costs but also offer higher efficiency as an alternative means to traditionally energy-intensive separation methods such as distillation, absorption, and extraction. Here, rational augmentation of the metal–organic framework, Mg-MOF-74, was designed in silico to enhance kinetic selectivity of the material, while imposing a minimal reduction in the adsorption working capacities for light hydrocarbons. From the computer-aided design, we synthesized 2,4,6-tri(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine-inserted Mg-MOF-74 (tpt-Mg-MOF-74) and successfully characterized the structure. This material can kinetically separate ethane/propane with an unprecedented diffusive selectivity of ∼49 owing to its distinctive pore size and provides evidence that metal–organic framework need not sacrifice pore volume for enhanced kinetic selectivity in separation applications.

div.span: Supporting Info (1)
SUBJECTS:

div.p: The separation of light hydrocarbon mixtures is one of the most important yet energy-intensive processes in the petrochemical industry. Solid adsorbent materials could potentially not only lower energy costs but also offer higher efficiency as an alternative means to traditionally energy-intensive separation methods such as distillation, absorption, and extraction. Here, rational augmentation of the metal–organic framework, Mg-MOF-74, was designed in silico to enhance kinetic selectivity of the material, while imposing a minimal reduction in the adsorption working capacities for light hydrocarbons. From the computer-aided design, we synthesized 2,4,6-tri(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine-inserted Mg-MOF-74 (tpt-Mg-MOF-74) and successfully characterized the structure. This material can kinetically separate ethane/propane with an unprecedented diffusive selectivity of ∼49 owing to its distinctive pore size and provides evidence that metal–organic framework need not sacrifice pore volume for enhanced kinetic selectivity in separation applications.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Current industrial light hydrocarbon (C
1
–C
4
) processing is supported by highly energy-intensive separation techniques that use cryogenic phase transitions of condensable hydrocarbon molecules.
(1,2)
Notably, recent natural gas revolution has allowed for substantial recovery of high-value natural gas liquids (NGLs, ethane, propane) that are major feedstock in the chemical industry.
(3)
The worldwide production of NGLs has reached an enormous scale of up to five million barrels per year.
(4)
This presents a significant opportunity for dramatic reductions in energy and carbon intensity by replacing traditional “thermal” separations with advanced separations based on engineered nanoporous materials that can physically “sieve” and fractionate the NGLs without requiring these gas species to undergo bulk gas to liquid phase transitions.

Because of their high surface areas and tunable pore chemistry, the separation capabilities of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have met or exceeded those achievable using conventional zeolite or carbon adsorbents.
(5−7)
Among numerous MOFs, M-MOF-74 [M
2
(dobdc), M = Mg, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn; dobdc
4–
= 2,5-dioxido-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate] is one of the most academically and industrially highlighted porous materials because of facile synthesis,
(8)
high density of exposed metal sites,
(9,10)
and high surface areas.
(11,12)
Because the unsaturated metal sites in these M-MOF-74 structures provide strong binding sites for gas molecules, various metal analogues of MOF-74 have been used in olefin/paraffin separations
(13,14)
and complex light hydrocarbon mixtures containing C
1
–C
3
gases.
(1,15,16)
2,5-dioxido-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (dobdc
4–
), the linker used to build MOF-74, is rigid and long enough to create a sufficiently large pore aperture (11.9 Å), which prompts fast kinetics for light hydrocarbon molecules (typically 3–6 Å in kinetic diameters) that enters the pores. However, such a large pore aperture cannot distinguish molecules with different sizes and shapes and, as such, provides little differentiation in terms of kinetics. This trade-off between adsorptive selectivity and diffusive selectivity sets a limitation to MOF-74 for hydrocarbon separation applications. To remedy this issue, one can simply choose a different MOF with a smaller aperture size, but this generally leads to a reduction in the working capacity of the light hydrocarbon gas molecules. As such, there is a pressing need to develop MOFs that simultaneously possess large gas uptake and high diffusion selectivity. To address this issue, we hypothesized that if one can alter the original MOF-74 structure to reduce its aperture size to the ultramicropore range (<6 Å)
(17)
with minimal loss in micropore volume where light hydrocarbon molecules “physically” sieve through this pore, then the aforementioned trade-off can be broken.

In our previous computational work, we selected IRMOF-74 as a base prototype material and implemented the ligand-insertion strategy. Using computational analysis, these structures showed an increase in the working capacity of CO
2
under humid flue gas conditions,
(18)
utility as a catalyst for enhanced ethane oxidation,
(19)
potential usage in water-harvesting material,
(20)
and reverse selectivity of hexane isomer separation.
(21)
As such, we initiated a plan to rationally select and insert ligands to reduce the pore aperture size of the pristine MOF-74 structure via the ligand-partition strategy. According to our simulation results, the rationally designed MOF-74 possesses the capability to sort light hydrocarbons with different kinetic diameters (4.0 Å for ethane and 4.2 Å for propane). Moreover, if the number of ligands is sufficiently small such that not all of the available metal sites are occupied with the ligands, the reduction in the working capacity will be small while diffusion will still be sensitive to the newly formed material, thereby breaking the trade-off between the working capacity and diffusion selectivity.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In this work, Mg
2
(dobdc) (CPO-27-Mg, Mg-MOF-74) was selected as the base MOF to apply the ligand-partition strategy. Mg
2
(dobdc) was synthesized using the previously reported method.
(10)
By inserting the ligand into the channel of the Mg-MOF-74 material, simultaneous metal–ligand bond (M–L bond) reaction occurred among the stoichiometric amounts of magnesium nitrate, 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid, and 2,4,6-tri(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) (products were denoted as Mg
2
(dobdc)-tpt) in heated
N
,
N
-dimethylformamide (DMF). The adsorption isotherms of ethane and propane for each sample were measured through a volumetric adsorption apparatus. The adsorption kinetic uptake curves were obtained through a custom pressure decaying apparatus (see the
Supporting Information
for experimental details).

Geometry optimization, calculation of binding energies, and NMR shielding constants were conducted using the first-principles calculations through the density functional theory (DFT), as implemented by the plane-wave pseudopotential approach in Quantum Espresso.
(22)
All molecular dynamics (MD) simulations used to analyze the diffusion behavior of the ethane and propane molecules were carried out using the large-scale atomic/molecular massively parallel simulator (LAMMPS) program.
(23)
Also, the pore volume of MOFs was calculated using the Zeo++ software
(24)
(see the
Supporting Information
for computational details).

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Among the M-MOF-74 structure with different metal types, Mg-MOF-74 was selected for our study, given its exceptionally high adsorption properties for small molecules.
(25−27)
Prior to experimental synthesis, the set of ligands that can potentially be inserted in the pores of the Mg-MOF-74 was identified from a list of all the linkers available in the CoRE MOF database.
(28)
From the set of 48 ligands
(29,30)
commonly used in the CoRE MOF data set, seven size-matching regulated ligands (7 Å <
D
ligand
< 10 Å) were selected as candidates to be inserted into the Mg-MOF-74 structure (
Figure 1
a). From this reduced set, the binding energies within the pores of the Mg-MOF-74 were computed using quantum calculations (see
Table S1
).

div.p: Figure 1. (a) Computational flow of the rational design used in this work. (b) Illustration of the pore space partitioned Mg-MOF-74 using ligands 2,4,6-tri(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt). The green and orange balls represent pore apertures in idealized Mg-MOF-74 and tpt-Mg-MOF-74, respectively. (c) PSD of Mg-MOF-74 (green) and tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (orange). The kinetic diameters of ethane and propane are represented in red and blue, respectively.

div.div:
Next, pore sizes of the ligand-inserted Mg-MOF-74 were calculated using Zeo++ to filter for MOFs with optimal molecular gas separation (ethane/propane). Finally, MD simulations were performed to obtain the self-diffusion coefficients of ethane and propane in these MOFs. Among the candidate ligands, the 2,4,6-tri(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) ligand was selected to possess the optimal properties for ethane/propane separation. Initially, the tpt ligand was inserted within the hexagonal channels of MOF-74, where each of the three nitrogen (one per 4-pyridyl ligand) atoms was next to the open metal sites (
Figure 1
b). The DFT binding energy of the tpt ligand inside the Mg-MOF-74 unit cell was computed to be −302.1 kJ/mol, which is significantly stronger than the binding energy of the DMF solvent (−107.6 kJ/mol), providing reliable evidence that the ligands would stay intact and not wash away during synthesis. With the inclusion of the tpt ligand, the pore limiting diameter of Mg-MOF-74 was reduced to around 4.2 Å, which is an ideal aperture size for ethane/propane separation. The pore size distribution (PSD)
(31)
for each structure was obtained, and it can be seen that the pore sizes of the tpt-Mg-MOF-74 are concentrated in the 3–4 Å range, while MOF-74 showed a prominent peak near 12 Å (
Figure 1
c). Based on these results, different diffusion properties of ethane and propane within the original Mg-MOF-74 structure and tpt-Mg-MOF-74 structure can be expected.

To verify the predictions made from the simulation data, both Mg-MOF-74 and tpt-Mg-MOF-74 were synthesized in this work. Mg-MOF-74 was synthesized using the method reported by Britt et al.,
(10)
and tpt-Mg-MOF-74 was synthesized using the extra-framework M–L bond reaction. In order to figure out the crystal morphology and particle size of the material, our sample was analyzed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (
Figure 2
a). The crystals of Mg-MOF-74 were synthesized with a particle size of less than 5 μm, which is consistent with previously reported experiments.
(33)
On the basis of the SEM images, it is reasonable to conclude that tpt-MOF-74 was well synthesized with the overall crystal structure intact. Next, the
13
C spectra of MOF-74 and ligand-inserted MOF were measured without
1
H decoupling. The spectra revealed good overall agreement between the calculated (based on the proposed structural model shown in
Figure 2
b) and the measured
13
C isotropic chemical shifts. The maximum discrepancy between the calculated and the measured values is 4 ppm, whereas for the rest, the deviation is below 2 ppm. It seems that the GIPAW
(34)
-based prediction of
13
C isotropic chemical shifts is quite reliable for the selected Mg-MOF-74 and that this approach can quite safely be used for the assignment of
13
C NMR spectra. Taking a look at the NMR spectra, we note that the Mg-MOF-74 structure exhibits narrow and small intensity lines, whereas the lines in the spectrum of tpt-Mg-MOF-74 are sharp with high intensity. Compared to the Mg-MOF-74 spectra, the two peaks appear at around 175 ppm in the tpt-Mg-MOF-74 NMR spectra. The signal at 172 ppm carbon (from the carbon of carbonyl in the linker) is present in both the Mg-MOF-74 and tpt-Mg-MOF-74. However, the signal at 174 ppm carbon is only present in tpt-MOF-74 because of the carbon atoms being positioned adjacent to 1,3,5-triazine on the three sides. Moreover, the NMR measurements on acid-digested samples indicate that the tpt ligands were inserted within the tpt-Mg-MOF74 structure (
Figure S6
). This is surprising because powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) used for structural identification (
Figure 2
c) does not indicate any notable differences in the crystallinity between the two samples. The peaks of simulated Mg-MOF-74 at 6.8° and 12° match well with the characteristic peaks of synthesized Mg-MOF-74 as there is good agreement between the two patterns, indicating that the as-synthesized sample has the exact correct structure with good crystallinity. Furthermore, we carried out the synchrotron powder diffraction study using the supramolecular crystallography (SMC) beamline to support the structural information of tpt-Mg-MOF-74. In the ideal computational designed structure, the tpt ligands were inserted such that the distance between the two tpt ligands is 6.7 Å along the channel direction in the
z
-axis (
Figure S3
), indicating that the tpt ligands are tightly packed, while occupying all possible metal sites (100% occupancy). The tpt-Mg-MOF-74 showed an additional diffraction peak at 7.9°. In the simulated XRD data, the diffraction peak of XRD located at 2 theta = 7.9° corresponds to the distance between the two tpt ligands along the channel direction in the
z
-axis (
Figure S7
). On the other hand, there is no significant difference in the XRD peak in both the calculation and experimental results for Mg-MOF-74 and Mg-MOF-74 containing the ligand. These results indicate that the inserted ligands retain the crystallinity of MOF structures.

div.p:
Figure 2. (a) SEM images of Mg-MOF-74 and tpt-Mg-MOF-74. (b) 13C solid-state NMR (ssNMR) data for Mg-MOF-74 and tpt-Mg-MOF-74. (c) PXRD data of Mg-MOF-74 (simulated, black), Mg-MOF-74(as-synthesized, blue), tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (simulated, green), and tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (as-synthesized, red) are shown. (d) N
2
sorption isotherm at 77 K by fitting with the Langmuir adsorption isotherm. The calculated BET surface area is given in parentheses. The filled and empty symbols represent adsorption and desorption, respectively. The PSD of Mg-MOF-74(blue) and tpt-Mg-MOF-74(red) in the inset is calculated using the Horvath-Kawazoe method.
(32)

div.div:
Finally, the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area decreased slightly (1560 m
2
/g for Mg-MOF-74 and 1294 m
2
/g for tpt-Mg-MOF-74) and a similar level of reduction was seen in the t-plot micropore volume (0.595 cm
3
/g for Mg-MOF-74 and 0.500 cm
3
/g for tpt-Mg-MOF-74) (
Figure 2
d).
(35)
Our computational results indicate that when ligands are fully inserted into all of the available metal sites, the percentage reduction in pore volume would be significantly lower (64 percentage volume loss), providing indirect evidence that the ligand occupancy might be relatively low in the experimental Mg-MOF-74 structure, which has only 16 percentage volume loss. We further confirmed the insertion of the tpt ligand into the pores of the Mg-MOF-74 and tpt-Mg-MOF-74 structures through the laser desorption ionization–time of flight (LDI-TOF) technique (
Figure S9
). Only the tpt-Mg-MOF-74 showed a peak at 311.32
m
/
z
, which corresponds to the molecular weight of the ionized tpt ligand. To clarify the amount of tpt loaded in the modified MOF, both activated and nonactivated samples were analyzed (
Figure S10
). However, because of the water adsorption of Mg-MOF-74, the activated sample underwent desolvation under 150 °C. At around 400 °C, structural degradation of MOFs began, and the mass sharply decreased. The dashed line indicates the point before structure degradation determined by the derivative thermogravimetric (DTG) curve. Both tpt-Mg-MOF-74 samples showed 2.4% (nonactivated) and 3.6% (activated) weight decrease compared to Mg-MOF-74. Through the calculation based on the remained magnesium oxide amount, the inserted tpt ligand amount can be calculated. For activated tpt-Mg-MOF-74, nearly 13% of the theoretical maximum amount of the tpt ligand was inserted and 10% for nonactivated tpt-Mg-MOF-74. These results coincided with elemental analysis (
Table S2
) and gas adsorption isotherm data.

Next, the single-component experimental adsorption isotherm data for ethane and propane in Mg-MOF-74 and tpt-Mg-MOF-74 were obtained at 298 K, and the data were fitted with the Langmuir model (
Figure 3
a). Prior to measuring the gas uptake, both MOFs were activated at high temperatures under a vacuum to remove the solvent and moisture from the ultramicropore. However, this activation process could lead to the destruction of the well-inserted array of tpt ligands because the high surface tension of solvent molecules undergoes a phase change from liquid to gas at such conditions. To avoid potential damage to the ligand-inserted structure, supercritical carbon dioxide (scCO
2
) treatment was used to minimize the mechanical stress applied to the MOF crystals via smooth phase transition from the supercritical to gas phase during activation.
(36)
The ethane uptake at 298 K and 1 bar in Mg-MOF-74 was measured to be 6.1 mmol/g, while the propane uptake was 6.6 mmol/g. On the other hand, adsorption uptakes of ethane and propane in tpt-Mg-MOF-74 were 5.4 and 6.1 mmol/g, respectively. There is only a slight reduction in the uptake amount, which might be the sign that not all of the open metal sites are being occupied by the tpt ligands.
(35)
Isosteric heat of adsorption for each gas was calculated through adsorption equilibrium data at 298, 308, and 318 K as well (
Figure S14
).

div.p:
Figure 3. (a) Ethane and propane adsorption isotherms for Mg-MOF-74 and tpt-Mg-MOF-74 at 298 K. The solid line indicates fit from the Langmuir model. (b) Single-component kinetic analysis of ethane and propane uptake. Left: ethane and propane uptake by Mg-MOF-74 as a function of the square root of time. Right: ethane and propane uptake by tpt-Mg-MOF-74 as a function of the square root of time. Calculated curve by fitting the uptake curve with a Fickian exponential boundary condition for entire points. (c) MSD of ethane and propane at 298 K for 2 ns. Left: MSD of ethane (red) and propane (blue) in Mg-MOF-74. Right: MSD of ethane (red) and propane (blue) in tpt-Mg-MOF-74. (d) Self-diffusion selectivity of ethane/propane. Left
y
-axis indicates the difference in self-diffusion selectivity at Mg-MOF-74 and tpt-Mg-MOF-74 by simulated data (represented in orange). Right
y
-axis indicates the difference in self-diffusion selectivity at Mg-MOF-74 and tpt-Mg-MOF-74 by experimental data (represented in purple). (e) Snapshot of ethane and propane in Mg-MOF-74 and tpt-Mg-MOF-74 at 298 K.

div.div:
From the time-dependent experimental gas uptake profiles for both Mg-MOF-74 and tpt-Mg-MOF-74 (
Figures S15–S18
), the average diffusivity of Mg-MOF-74 for ethane and propane was calculated to be 28.3 × 10
–12
cm
2
/s and 13.7 × 10
–12
cm
2
/s. In tpt-Mg-MOF-74, the average diffusivities for ethane and propane were 30.3 × 10
–12
cm
2
/s and 0.62 × 10
–12
m
2
/s, respectively (
Figure 3
b). While the adsorption kinetics between ethane and propane did not show a large difference in Mg-MOF-74, ethane molecules diffused much faster in tpt-MOF-74 [the transport diffusivity and thermodynamically corrected diffusivity of ethane and propane molecules are summarized, respectively (
Table 1
)]. MD simulations were also conducted in the two structures, and the self-diffusivity of ethane and propane was obtained from the mean-squared displacement (MSD) (
Figure 3
c). For the Mg-MOF-74 structures, the diffusivities of ethane and propane have similar values of 20.1 × 10
–12
m
2
/s and 16.1 × 10
–12
m
2
/s, respectively. However, in the case of the tpt-Mg-MOF-74 structure with 100% ligand occupancy (where the maximum number of tpt ligands were occupied in the Mg-MOF-74 structure), diffusivities of ethane and propane were significantly different at 8.54 × 10
–12
m
2
/s and 4.25 × 10
–14
m
2
/s, respectively. The reduction in the pore size due to the inclusion of the ligands led to significant kinetic separation of ethane and propane, as surmised from our screening criterion. The tpt-Mg-MOF-74 showed a significantly high ethane/propane selectivity of 213 using the computational data compared with that of Mg-MOF-74 (selectivity of ∼1.26). Similarly, the kinetic selectivity from experimental data was obtained to be 49 for tpt-Mg-MOF-74 and 2.07 for Mg-MOF-74 (
Figure 3
d). The MD snapshots are presented to visualize the trajectory of the ethane and propane molecules. The mobility of the ethane and propane molecules in 100% ligand occupancy seems to be largely dominated by their kinetic diameter (
Figure 3
e). As observed from the MSD data, both ethane and propane molecules easily diffuse through the Mg-MOF-74 channels. In the case of the tpt-Mg-MOF-74 structure, the ethane molecule has a smaller kinetic diameter than the aperture size and thus can freely rotate, leading to relatively fast diffusion despite the steric effect from ligand insertion. In contrast, propane molecules that have larger kinetic diameters than the aperture size slowly diffuse through the channels and are “stuck” inside the cage created between the two neighboring ligands, which results in overall poor diffusivity.
Table 1. Experimental Transport Diffusivity and Thermodynamically Corrected Diffusivity under Partial Pressure

p
/

,

div.div:
To quantify the effect of the ligand proportion to the diffusion selectivity, the proportion of all available occupied sites was varied from 20 to 100% (
Figure 4
, and see
Figures S21–S24
for individual ligand proportion data). The diffusivity of ethane and propane molecules reduces with the increasing proportion of the ligands (
Figure 4
). At a relatively low occupancy (<60%), the kinetic selectivity between ethane and propane is small as an ample amount of pore volume seems to free the movement of both the gas molecules. However, at a higher occupancy, the kinetic selectivity increases significantly as the propane diffusion selectivity decreases much more than that of ethane due to hindrance. From
Figure 4
, one can see that the proportion of the ligands plays a crucial role in maintaining an appropriate balance between the high selectivity and adsorption capacity of the gas molecules.

div.p:
Figure 4. Diffusivity and kinetic selectivity versus inserted tpt ligand proportion in Mg-MOF-74. Left
y
-axis indicates the diffusivity of ethane and propane represented by red and blue, respectively (closed circles with line). Right
y
-axis indicates the kinetic selectivity (closed green squares with line).

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div: In this work, the tpt ligand-inserted Mg-MOF-74 material was rationally designed from the molecular level using our computational approach, and the resulting structure was experimentally synthesized. The resulting reduction in the pore size led to significant enhancement in the ethane/propane separation selectivity. Despite the order of magnitude increase in the kinetic selectivity, resulting decrease in the pore volume was negligible, demonstrating that tunable design can break the traditional trade-off that one envisioned with respect to kinetic selectivity and adsorption capacity.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.p:
The Supporting Information is available free of charge at
https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c01657
.

H solution NMR data. (a) tpt ligand, (b) Mg-MOF-74, and (c) tpt-Mg-MOF-74. All samples were dissolved by D

The sepn. of hydrocarbons with carbon nos. in the 1-3 range is of great significance in the purifn. of natural gas, prodn. of ethylene and propylene with the required 99.5%+ purity levels as feeds to polymn. reactors, and sepn. of ethyne from mixts. with ethylene. In this study the performances of a total of 19 different MOFs, carefully selected to span a wide range of functionalities, were evaluated for a variety of sepn. tasks. For all sepn. tasks investigated, MOFs with high d. of open metal sites, CoMOF-74, MgMOF-74, and FeMOF-74, have significantly better sepn. potential than other MOFs, ZIFs or zeolites that have been suggested in the literature. Of particular significance is the possibility offered by CoMOF-74, MgMOF-74, and FeMOF-74 for "fractionating" a 6-component CH4/C2H2/C2H4/C2H6/C3H6/C3H8 mixt. to yield individual pure components. Such sepns. are likely to have a significant industrial impact, resulting in significant energy savings when compared to current technologies that rely on distn.

A review. In the process industries, the sepn. of mixts. of hydrocarbons is important both for the prepn. of feedstocks and for use as end products. The constituents, hydrocarbons, are either aliph. or arom., satd. or unsatd., with a large variation in the no. of carbon atoms. Using microporous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), a no. of different sepn. strategies can be employed to achieve the desired sepn. performance. The strategies include selective binding with the metal atoms of the framework, exploiting differences in mol. packing efficiencies within the ordered pore structures, utilizing selectivities based on the framework flexibility and gate-opening mechanisms, and mol. sieving. Various strategies are discussed in this article, along with perspectives for future research and development for improving the sepn. performance.

Two tailor-made microporous metal-org. framework (MOF) membranes were successfully fabricated on nickel screens by secondary growth. The effect of pore structures on gas sepn. was examd. by means of single and binary gas permeation tests. The MOF JUC-150 membrane with its ultra-micropores showed marked preferential permeance to H2 relative to other gas mols. The selectivity factors of this membrane were 26.3, 17.1 and 38.7 for H2/CH4, H2/N2 and H2/CO2, resp., at room temp. To the best of our knowledge, these values represent unprecedentedly high sepn. selectivity among those for all MOF membranes reported to date. The JUC-150 membrane also shows high thermal stability and outstanding sepn. performance at a high temp. of 200 °C. The sepn. performance of these membranes persists even after more than 1 yr exposure to air. The superiority of the tailored pore size, high selectivity for H2 over other gases, significant stability and recyclability make these materials potential candidates for industrial H2 recycling applications.

Room temp. synthesis of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) was developed for four known MOFs: MOF-5, MOF-74, MOF-177, and MOF-199. A new isoreticular metal framework (IRMOF), IRMOF-0, having the same cubic topol. as MOF-5, was synthesized from acetylenedicarboxylic acid using this method to accommodate the thermal sensitivity of the linker. Despite acetylenedicarboxylate being the shortest straight linker that can be made into an IRMOF, IRMOF-0 forms as a doubly interpenetrating structure, owing to the rod-like nature of the linker.

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) can contain open metal sites (OMS) or coordinatively unsaturated sites (CUS) or open coordination sites (OCS) when vacant Lewis acid sites on the metal ions or cluster nodes have been generated. This review combines for the first time all aspects of OMS in MOFs, starting from different preparation strategies over theoretical studies on the effects of OMS with host-guest interactions up to distinct OMS-MOF applications. In the experimental part the focus of this review is on MOFs with proven OMS formation which are not only invoked but are clearly verified by analytical methods.

Selective capture of CO2, which is essential for natural gas purifn. and CO2 sequestration, has been reported in zeolites, porous membranes, and amine solns. However, all such systems require substantial energy input for release of captured CO2, leading to low energy efficiency and high cost. A new class of materials named metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) has also been demonstrated to take up voluminous amts. of CO2. However, these studies have been largely limited to equil. uptake measurements, which are a poor predictor of sepn. ability, rather than the more industrially relevant kinetic (dynamic) capacity. Here, we report that a known MOF, Mg-MOF-74, with open magnesium sites, rivals competitive materials in CO2 capture, with 8.9 wt. % dynamic capacity, and undergoes facile CO2 release at significantly lower temp., 80 °C. Mg-MOF-74 offers an excellent balance between dynamic capacity and regeneration. These results demonstrate the potential of MOFs with open metal sites as efficient CO2 capture media.

Vapor-assisted dry-gel synthesis of the metal-org. framework-74 (MOF-74) structure, specifically Ni-MOF-74 produced from synthetic precursors using an org.-water hybrid solvent system, showed a very high yield (>90% with respect to 2,5-dihydroxyterepthalic acid) and enhanced performance. The Ni-MOF-74 obtained showed improved sorption characteristics towards CO2 and the refrigerant fluorocarbon dichlorodifluoromethane. Unlike conventional synthesis, which takes 72 h using the tetrahydrofuran-water system, this kinetic study showed that Ni-MOF-74 forms within 12 h under dry-gel conditions with similar performance characteristics, and exhibits its best performance characteristics even after 24 h of heating. In the dry-gel conversion method, the phys. sepn. of the solvent and precursor mixt. allows for recycling of the solvent. We demonstrated efficient solvent recycling (up to three times) that resulted in significant cost benefits. The scaled-up manufg. cost of Ni-MOF-74 synthesized via our dry-gel method is 45% of conventional synthesis cost. Thus, for bulk prodn. of the MOFs, the proposed vapor-assisted, dry-gel method is efficient, simple, and inexpensive when compared to the conventional synthesis method.

This paper describes the prepn. and characterization of nanoscaled M-MOF-74/CPO-27-M (M = Mg, Mn, Co, Ni, and Zn) materials at room temp. Some of the so-formed crystals are the smallest ones of any metal-org. framework (MOF) material (and, to the best of the authors' knowledge, of any microporous material) ever reported. They are at the limit of being able to diffract, particularly those forming the Co- and Ni-MOF-74 samples. Consequently, unequivocal identification as the cryst. MOF-74 phase was deduced by combining other characterization techniques rather than powder x-ray diffraction. These small crystals are unstable as isolated ones, so they form steady and robust aggregates, whose mech. properties strongly depend on the crystal size. The particles that result from the fusion of nanocrystals smaller than 10 nm (more properly denoted as nanodomains) could not be disaggregated by conventional ultrasonic and graining techniques. On the contrary, agglomerates of crystals larger than 10 nm are dissociable in discrete crystals. It allows characterizing Zn-MOF-74 nanocrystals by advanced electron microscopy methods. Cs-cor. scanning TEM (STEM) provided, for the 1st time, quasi at. resoln. images of MOFs, which are esp. unstable under electronic radiation. The magnitude of the crystal size of M-MOF-74 is tentatively assocd. with the soly. of the metal source.

The energy costs assocd. with large-scale industrial sepn. of light hydrocarbons by cryogenic distn. could potentially be lowered through development of selective solid adsorbents that operate at higher temps. Here, the metal-org. framework Fe2(dobdc) (dobdc4- : 2,5-dioxido-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) is demonstrated to exhibit excellent performance characteristics for sepn. of ethylene/ethane and propylene/propane mixts. at 318 K. Breakthrough data obtained for these mixts. provide exptl. validation of simulations, which in turn predict high selectivities and capacities of this material for the fractionation of methane/ethane/ethylene/acetylene mixts., removal of acetylene impurities from ethylene, and membrane-based olefin/paraffin sepns. Neutron powder diffraction data confirm a side-on coordination of acetylene, ethylene, and propylene at the iron(II) centers, while also providing solid-state structural characterization of the much weaker interactions of ethane and propane with the metal.

An increase in demand for energy efficient processes for the sepn. of satd. and unsatd. light hydrocarbons mixts. drives the need of noncryogenic processes. The adsorptive sepn. using Metal-Org. Frameworks with coordinatively unsatd. metal sites may provide a cost-effective alternative due to the strong binding of the metal cation with the unsatd. hydrocarbons. Since expts. on adsorption equil. of gas mixts. are challenging, we propose classical force field based simulations to analyze the ability of MOF-74 with different metal substitutions for the sepn. of C2 and C3 olefin/paraffin binary mixts. We parametrized the force field by fitting to available exptl. single-component adsorption isotherms of ethane, ethene, propane, and propene in M-MOF-74 (M=Co, Fe, Mn, and Ni). The force field was validated for a variety of temps. ranged from 273 K to 353 K. We then conducted Monte Carlo simulations in the Grand-Canonical ensemble to elucidate the adsorption mechanisms of the satd./unsatd. hydrocarbon mixts., at 318 K and 353 K. We computed the adsorption isotherms, and from these the adsorption selectivity, and addressed the variations of MOF properties with different metal cations. Fe-based MOF-74 appears the best option for both ethane/ethene and propane/propene sepn. applications. This finding partly agrees with previous work based on the Ideal Adsorbed Soln. Theory.

An increase in demand for energy efficient processes for the sepn. of a mixt. of hydrocarbons drives the need for understanding metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) that can provide better noncryogenic alternatives for the fractionation of hydrocarbon mixts. Here we study the structure and properties of a metal-org. framework, Fe-MOF-74, and its effectiveness to sep. C1-C3 hydrocarbon mixts. The binding of these hydrocarbons to the open metal sites of Fe-MOF-74 has been investigated using a meta-generalized gradient approxn. d. functional, M06-L, which has previously been validated for systems contg. transition metals. For interpretive purposes, charge model 5 (CM5) is used to det. the partial at. charges on the metal cations and the oxygen atoms of the ligands surrounding these metal centers. Our computations show preferential binding to the metal center of Fe-MOF-74 of unsatd. hydrocarbons over satd. ones in agreement with exptl. results, and the calcd. binding energies are in semiquant. agreement with expt. The results are analyzed in terms of various factors contributing to the binding, including structural distortion, electrostatics, damped dispersion, charge transfer, back bonding, and ligand field effects on the d orbitals. The CM5 charges are not sensitive to small differences in structure.

The application of a metal-org. framework (MOF) has expanded into the area of heterogeneous catalysis, gas storage and sepn., drug delivery, and lightwt. magnets. Herein, we investigate the nature of olefin and paraffin binding on Fe/MOF-74 and identify several factors that det. sepn. efficiency using the first-principles calcns. The calcd. binding energies and magnetic orderings are in excellent agreement with those obsd. in expts. While the olefin strongly interacts with Fe atoms through a well-known π-complexation, the HOMO - 1(2) of the paraffin weakly interacts with Fe atoms without back-donation, facilitating the olefin-paraffin sepn. primarily. However, the mutual gas-gas interactions and magnetic transitions of the MOF host also contribute significantly to the total binding energy of each gas mol. as much as 2-28% and 6-8%, resp., emphasizing the necessity that these subtle effects must be handled carefully when considering selective binding with small energy differences. In particular, Fe/MOF-74 is shown to be a unique system where the guest-dependent magnetic transition obsd. only for the olefin adsorption is a secondary reason for the high olefin-paraffin adsorption selectivity measured. The understanding of the hydrocarbon binding energetics can provide a way to modify MOFs for enhanced sepn./sorption properties that can be complemented by principles of kinetic sepn.

Among various class of materials, metal-org. frameworks (MOF) are a most promising candidate for flue gas CO2 capture. In particular, M-MOF-74, where M = different metals, are equipped with open metal sites which can lead to very high CO2 uptake in post-combustion flue gas conditions. However, these structures are known to have poor CO2 capture performance under humid conditions since water mols. strongly bind to the unsatd. metal sites, out-competing CO2. This computational study used a pore space partition strategy via symmetry-matching regulated ligand insertion within the Mg-MOF-74 and Zn-MOF-74 structures to mitigate the water deterioration effect. For Zn-MOF-74, higher selectivity and larger CO2 uptake in binary mixt. conditions were obtained, demonstrating that redn. in MOF pore size is a viable strategy to capture CO2 under humid post-combustion conditions.

Efficient conversion of ethane into valuable materials is important with the availability of new natural gas resources. Recently, metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) with open iron sites (i.e., Fe0.1Mg1.9-MOF-74) have been shown to be promising material for catalyzing ethane to ethanol. In this computational study, various size-matching ligands are inserted into the Fe0.1Mg1.9-MOF-74 structure to further optimize this reaction. Our d. functional theory calcns. show that the presence of ligands enhances the binding affinity of the oxygen atoms of N2O to the iron atoms in the framework, thereby leading to an improvement in the oxidizing process. Furthermore, the reaction pathways for the new structures show reduced enthalpy barrier in the rate-detg. step in the oxidn. of ethane reaction cycle compared to the original Fe0.1Mg1.9-MOF-74. These findings provide ways in which the performance of the Fe0.1Mg1.9-MOF-74 can be optimized for next-generation catalysts.

Harvesting water from air is one of the key environmental related issues facing humanity in recent years. In this study, we demonstrate that the Ni-IRMOF74-III metal-org. framework structure attached with azopyridine mols. can potentially undergo photochem. induced cis/trans transition, leading to significant enhancement in the H2O working capacity. Specifically, grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations indicate an ultrahigh 0.20 kg kg-1 of H2O working capacity at 25°C adsorption and 65°C desorption conditions. More importantly, given that the cis/trans switching is predominantly responsible for the discrepancy in the H2O uptake, even in the mild condition of 35°C desorption (10°C diurnal temp. swing), the H2O working capacity is still very high at 0.18 kg kg-1. Our theor. findings provide a blueprint to design the next generation water harvesting materials that can operate in natural conditions to expand its applicability in different regions around the world.

Fast parallel algorithms for short-range molecular dynamics
Plimpton, Steve

Three parallel algorithms for classical mol. dynamics are presented. The first assigns each processor a fixed subset of atoms; the second assigns each a fixed subset of inter-at. forces to compute; the third assigns each a fixed spatial region. The algorithms are suitable for mol. dynamics models which can be difficult to parallelize efficiently - those with short-range forces where the neighbors of each atom change rapidly. They can be implemented on any distributed-memory parallel machine which allows for message-passing of data between independently executing processors. The algorithms are tested on a std. Lennard-Jones benchmark problem for system sizes ranging from 500 to 100,000,000 atoms on several parallel supercomputers - the nCUBE 2, Intel iPSC/860 and Paragon, and Cray T3D. Comparing the results to the fastest reported vectorized Cray Y-MP and C90 algorithm shows that the current generation of parallel machines is competitive with conventional vector supercomputers even for small problems. For large problems, the spatial algorithm achieves parallel efficiencies of 90% and a 1840-node Intel Paragon performs up to 165 faster than a single Cray C90 processor. Trade-offs between the three algorithms and guidelines for adapting them to more complex mol. dynamics simulations are also discussed.

Cryst. porous materials have a variety of uses, such as for catalysis and sepn. Identifying suitable materials for a given application can, in principle, be done by screening material databases. Such a screening requires automated high-throughput anal. tools that calc. structural properties for all materials contained in a database so they can be compared with search queries, grouped or classified. One important aspect of the structural anal. of materials such as zeolites and metal org. frameworks is the investigation of the geometrical parameters describing pores. Here, we present algorithms and tools to efficiently calc. some of these important parameters. Our tools are based on the Voronoi decompn., which for a given arrangement of atoms in a periodic domain provides a graph representation of the void space. The resulting Voronoi network is analyzed to obtain the diam. of the largest included sphere and the largest free sphere, which are two geometrical parameters that are frequently used to describe pore geometry. Accessibility of nodes in the network is also detd. for a given guest mol. and the resulting information is later used to retrieve dimensionality of channel systems as well as in Monte Carlo sampling of accessible surfaces and vols. The presented algorithms are implemented in a software tool, Zeo++, which includes a modified version of the Voro++ library. We present example applications of our algorithms and tools using zeolite frameworks currently listed in the Atlas of Zeolite Frameworks.

The main challenge for gas storage and sepn. in nanoporous materials is that many mols. of interest adsorb too weakly to be effectively retained. Instead of synthetically modifying the internal surface structure of the entire bulk-as is typically done to enhance adsorption-here we show that post exposure of a prototypical porous metal-org. framework to ethylenediamine can effectively retain a variety of weakly adsorbing mols. (for example, CO, CO2, SO2, C2H4, NO) inside the materials by forming a monolayer-thick cap at the external surface of microcrystals. Furthermore, this capping mechanism, based on hydrogen bonding as explained by ab initio modeling, opens the door for potential selectivity. For example, water mols. are shown to disrupt the hydrogen-bonded amine network and diffuse through the cap without hindrance and fully displace/release the retained small mols. out of the metal-org. framework at room temp. These findings may provide alternative strategies for gas storage, delivery and sepn.

Using d. functional theory, the authors systematically computed and investigated the binding enthalpies of 14 different small mols. in a series of isostructural metal-org. frameworks, M-MOF-74, with M = Mg, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn. The small mols. considered include major flue-gas components, trace gases, and small hydrocarbons, i.e., H2, CO, CO2, H2O, H2S, N2, NH3, SO2, CH4, C2H2, C2H4, C2H6, C3H6, and C3H8. In total, the adsorption energetics of 140 unique systems are presented and discussed. Dispersion interactions were included by employing a non-local van der Waals d. functional, vdW-DF2. Hubbard U corrections were applied to the localized d electrons of transition metal atoms, and the impact of such corrections was assessed quant. For systems for which measured binding enthalpies have been reported, these calcns. lead to excellent overall agreement with exptl. detd. structures and isosteric heats of adsorption. For systems that have yet to be realized or characterized, this study provides quant. predictions, establishes a better understanding of the role of different transition-metal cations in small-mol. binding at open-metal sites, and identifies routes for predicting potential candidates for energy-related gas-sepn. applications. For example, the authors predict that Cu-MOF-74 will exhibit selectivity of CO2 over H2O and that Mn-MOF-74 can be used to sep. trace flue-gas impurities and toxic gases from gas mixts.

Royal Society of Chemistry

A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are hybrid porous materials with many potential applications, which intimately depend on the presence of chem. functionality either at the org. linkers and/or at the metal nodes. Functionality that cannot be introduced into MOFs directly via de novo syntheses can be accessed through post-synthesis modification (PSM) on the reactive moieties of the linkers and/or nodes without disrupting the metal-linker bonds. Even more intriguing methods that go beyond PSM are herein termed building block replacement (BBR) which encompasses (i) solvent-assisted linker exchange (SALE), (ii) nonbridging ligand replacement, and (iii) transmetalation. These 1-step or tandem BBR processes involve exchanging key structural components of the MOF, which in turn should allow for the evolution of protoMOF structures (i.e., the use of a parent MOF as a template) to design MOFs composed of completely new components, presumably via single crystal to single crystal transformations. The influence of building block replacement on the stability and properties of MOFs are discussed, and some insights into their mechanistic aspects are provided. Future perspectives providing a glimpse into how these techniques can lead to various unexplored areas of MOF chem. are also presented.

A review. The efforts to implement pore space partition (PSP) in metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) and impact of PSP on gas uptake performance are reviewed. In the synthetic design of PSP, it is helpful to distinguish between factors that contribute to the framework formation and factors that serve the purpose of PSP. Because of the need for complementary structural roles, the synthesis of MOFs with PSP often involves multicomponent systems including mixed ligands, mixed inorg. nodes, or both. It is possible to accomplish both framework formation and PSP with a single type of polyfunctional ligands that use some functional groups (called framework-forming group) for framework formation and the remaining functional groups (called pore-partition group) for PSP. Alternatively, framework formation and PSP can be shouldered by different chem. species. For example, in a mixed-ligand system, one ligand (called framework-forming agent) can play the role of the framework formation while the other type of ligand (called pore-partition agent) can assume the role of PSP. PSP is sensitive to the types of inorg. secondary building units (SBUs). The coexistence of SBUs complementary in charge, connectivity, and so on can promote PSP. The use of heterometallic systems can promote the diversity of SBUs coexistent under a given condition. Heterometallic system with metal ions of different oxidn. states also provides the charge tunability of SBUs and the overall framework, providing an addnl. level of control in self-assembly and ultimately in the materials' properties. Of particular interest is the PSP in MIL-88 type (acs-type topol.) structure, which has led to a huge family of CPMs (called pacs CPMs, pacs = partitioned acs) exhibiting low isosteric heat of adsorption and yet superior CO2 uptake capacity.

Cryst. porous materials have many applications, including catalysis and sepns. Identifying suitable materials for a given application can be achieved by screening material databases. Such a screening requires automated high-throughput anal. tools that characterize and represent pore landscapes with descriptors, which can be compared using similarity measures in order to select, group and classify materials. Here, we discuss algorithms for the calcn. of two types of pore landscape descriptors: pore size distributions and stochastic rays. These descriptors provide histogram representations that encode the geometrical properties of pore landscapes. Their calcn. involves the Voronoi decompn. as a technique to map and characterize accessible void space inside porous materials. Moreover, we demonstrate pore landscape comparisons for materials from the International Zeolite Assocn. (IZA) database of zeolite frameworks, and illustrate how the choice of pore descriptor and similarity measure affects the perspective of material similarity exhibiting a particular emphasis and sensitivity to certain aspects of structures.

Since its publication, the G. Horvath and K. Kawazoe (H-K) (1983) equation has been rapidly and widely adopted for calcg. the micropore size distribution from a single adsorption isotherm measured at a subcrit. temp. (e.g. N2 at 77 K or Ar at 87 K). In the H-K formulation, the ideal Henry's law (linearity) is assumed for the isotherm, even though the actual isotherms invariably follow the typical type I behavior, which is well represented by the Langmuir isotherm. The H-K formulation is modified by including the nonlinearity of the isotherm. Inclusion of nonlinearity results in sharpening of the pore size distribution and shifting of its peak position to a smaller size. Furthermore, the H-K equation is extended to spherical pores, and the improved H-K equation for spherical pores by including isotherm nonlinearity is also given. It is shown that the spherical-pore model is particularly useful for zeolites with cavities. Using the literature isotherm data, the improved H-K equations for three pore geometries (slit shape, cylinder and sphere) are compared with the original H-K equations. Clear improvements are seen in the calcd. micropore size distributions by using the improved H-K equations.

Postsynthetic functionalization of magnesium 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalate (Mg-MOF-74) with tetraethylenepentamine (TEPA) resulted in improved CO2 adsorption performance under dry and humid conditions. XPS, elemental anal., and neutron powder diffraction studies indicated that TEPA was incorporated throughout the MOF particle, although it coordinated preferentially with the unsatd. metal sites located in the immediate proximity to the surface. Neutron and X-ray powder diffraction analyses showed that the MOF structure was preserved after amine incorporation, with slight changes in the lattice parameters. The adsorption capacity of the functionalized amino-Mg-MOF-74 (TEPA-MOF) for CO2 was as high as 26.9 wt. % vs. 23.4 wt. % for the original MOF due to the extra binding sites provided by the multiunit amines. The degree of functionalization with the amines was found to be important in enhancing CO2 adsorption, as the optimal surface coverage improved performance and stability under both pure CO2 and CO2/H2O coadsorption, and with partially satd. surface coverage, optimal CO2 capacity could be achieved under both wet and dry conditions by a synergistic binding of CO2 to the amines as well as metal centers.

A review. In 2001, Mauri and Pickard introduced the gauge including projected augmented wave (GIPAW) method that enabled for the first time the calcn. of all-electron NMR parameters in solids, i.e. accounting for periodic boundary conditions. The GIPAW method roots in the plane wave pseudopotential formalism of the d. functional theory (DFT), and avoids the use of the cluster approxn. This method has undoubtedly revitalized the interest in quantum chem. calcns. in the solid-state NMR community. It has quickly evolved and improved so that the calcn. of the key components of NMR interactions, namely the shielding and elec. field gradient tensors, has now become a routine for most of the common nuclei studied in NMR. Availability of reliable implementations in several software packages (CASTEP, Quantum Espresso, PARATEC) make its usage more and more increasingly popular, maybe indispensable in near future for all material NMR studies. The majority of nuclei of the periodic table have already been investigated by GIPAW, and because of its high accuracy it is quickly becoming an essential tool for interpreting and understanding exptl. NMR spectra, providing reliable assignments of the obsd. resonances to crystallog. sites or enabling a priori prediction of NMR data. The continuous increase of computing power makes ever larger (and thus more realistic) systems amenable to first-principles anal. In the near future perspectives, as the incorporation of dynamical effects and/or disorder are still at their early developments, these areas will certainly be the prime target.

Cryst. metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as a highly desirable class of solid-state materials. Some of their most attractive features include exceptionally high porosities as well as surface areas. A key aspect to the realization of high porosity is the removal of guest mols. from the framework while still maintaining its structural integrity (i.e., "activation"). This contribution highlights the strategies utilized to date for activating MOFs, including: (i) conventional heating and vacuum; (ii) solvent-exchange; (iii) supercrit. CO2 (scCO2) exchange; (iv) freeze-drying; and (v) chem. treatment.

A review. In the process industries, the sepn. of mixts. of hydrocarbons is important both for the prepn. of feedstocks and for use as end products. The constituents, hydrocarbons, are either aliph. or arom., satd. or unsatd., with a large variation in the no. of carbon atoms. Using microporous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), a no. of different sepn. strategies can be employed to achieve the desired sepn. performance. The strategies include selective binding with the metal atoms of the framework, exploiting differences in mol. packing efficiencies within the ordered pore structures, utilizing selectivities based on the framework flexibility and gate-opening mechanisms, and mol. sieving. Various strategies are discussed in this article, along with perspectives for future research and development for improving the sepn. performance.

Two tailor-made microporous metal-org. framework (MOF) membranes were successfully fabricated on nickel screens by secondary growth. The effect of pore structures on gas sepn. was examd. by means of single and binary gas permeation tests. The MOF JUC-150 membrane with its ultra-micropores showed marked preferential permeance to H2 relative to other gas mols. The selectivity factors of this membrane were 26.3, 17.1 and 38.7 for H2/CH4, H2/N2 and H2/CO2, resp., at room temp. To the best of our knowledge, these values represent unprecedentedly high sepn. selectivity among those for all MOF membranes reported to date. The JUC-150 membrane also shows high thermal stability and outstanding sepn. performance at a high temp. of 200 °C. The sepn. performance of these membranes persists even after more than 1 yr exposure to air. The superiority of the tailored pore size, high selectivity for H2 over other gases, significant stability and recyclability make these materials potential candidates for industrial H2 recycling applications.

A new isoreticular metal framework (IRMOF), IRMOF-0, having the same cubic topol. as MOF-5, was synthesized from acetylenedicarboxylic acid using this method to accommodate the thermal sensitivity of the linker. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) can contain open metal sites (OMS) or coordinatively unsaturated sites (CUS) or open coordination sites (OCS) when vacant Lewis acid sites on the metal ions or cluster nodes have been generated. This review combines for the first time all aspects of OMS in MOFs, starting from different preparation strategies over theoretical studies on the effects of OMS with host-guest interactions up to distinct OMS-MOF applications. In the experimental part the focus of this review is on MOFs with proven OMS formation which are not only invoked but are clearly verified by analytical methods.

Selective capture of CO2, which is essential for natural gas purifn. and CO2 sequestration, has been reported in zeolites, porous membranes, and amine solns. However, all such systems require substantial energy input for release of captured CO2, leading to low energy efficiency and high cost. A new class of materials named metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) has also been demonstrated to take up voluminous amts. of CO2. However, these studies have been largely limited to equil. uptake measurements, which are a poor predictor of sepn. ability, rather than the more industrially relevant kinetic (dynamic) capacity. Here, we report that a known MOF, Mg-MOF-74, with open magnesium sites, rivals competitive materials in CO2 capture, with 8.9 wt. % dynamic capacity, and undergoes facile CO2 release at significantly lower temp., 80 °C. Mg-MOF-74 offers an excellent balance between dynamic capacity and regeneration. These results demonstrate the potential of MOFs with open metal sites as efficient CO2 capture media.

Vapor-assisted dry-gel synthesis of the metal-org. framework-74 (MOF-74) structure, specifically Ni-MOF-74 produced from synthetic precursors using an org.-water hybrid solvent system, showed a very high yield (>90% with respect to 2,5-dihydroxyterepthalic acid) and enhanced performance. The Ni-MOF-74 obtained showed improved sorption characteristics towards CO2 and the refrigerant fluorocarbon dichlorodifluoromethane. Unlike conventional synthesis, which takes 72 h using the tetrahydrofuran-water system, this kinetic study showed that Ni-MOF-74 forms within 12 h under dry-gel conditions with similar performance characteristics, and exhibits its best performance characteristics even after 24 h of heating. In the dry-gel conversion method, the phys. sepn. of the solvent and precursor mixt. allows for recycling of the solvent. We demonstrated efficient solvent recycling (up to three times) that resulted in significant cost benefits. The scaled-up manufg. cost of Ni-MOF-74 synthesized via our dry-gel method is 45% of conventional synthesis cost. Thus, for bulk prodn. of the MOFs, the proposed vapor-assisted, dry-gel method is efficient, simple, and inexpensive when compared to the conventional synthesis method.

This paper describes the prepn. and characterization of nanoscaled M-MOF-74/CPO-27-M (M = Mg, Mn, Co, Ni, and Zn) materials at room temp. Some of the so-formed crystals are the smallest ones of any metal-org. framework (MOF) material (and, to the best of the authors' knowledge, of any microporous material) ever reported. They are at the limit of being able to diffract, particularly those forming the Co- and Ni-MOF-74 samples. Consequently, unequivocal identification as the cryst. MOF-74 phase was deduced by combining other characterization techniques rather than powder x-ray diffraction. These small crystals are unstable as isolated ones, so they form steady and robust aggregates, whose mech. properties strongly depend on the crystal size. The particles that result from the fusion of nanocrystals smaller than 10 nm (more properly denoted as nanodomains) could not be disaggregated by conventional ultrasonic and graining techniques. On the contrary, agglomerates of crystals larger than 10 nm are dissociable in discrete crystals. It allows characterizing Zn-MOF-74 nanocrystals by advanced electron microscopy methods. Cs-cor. scanning TEM (STEM) provided, for the 1st time, quasi at. resoln. images of MOFs, which are esp. unstable under electronic radiation. The magnitude of the crystal size of M-MOF-74 is tentatively assocd. with the soly. of the metal source.

An increase in demand for energy efficient processes for the sepn. of satd. and unsatd. light hydrocarbons mixts. drives the need of noncryogenic processes. The adsorptive sepn. using Metal-Org. Frameworks with coordinatively unsatd. metal sites may provide a cost-effective alternative due to the strong binding of the metal cation with the unsatd. hydrocarbons. Since expts. on adsorption equil. of gas mixts. are challenging, we propose classical force field based simulations to analyze the ability of MOF-74 with different metal substitutions for the sepn. of C2 and C3 olefin/paraffin binary mixts. We parametrized the force field by fitting to available exptl. single-component adsorption isotherms of ethane, ethene, propane, and propene in M-MOF-74 (M=Co, Fe, Mn, and Ni). The force field was validated for a variety of temps. ranged from 273 K to 353 K. We then conducted Monte Carlo simulations in the Grand-Canonical ensemble to elucidate the adsorption mechanisms of the satd./unsatd. hydrocarbon mixts., at 318 K and 353 K. We computed the adsorption isotherms, and from these the adsorption selectivity, and addressed the variations of MOF properties with different metal cations. Fe-based MOF-74 appears the best option for both ethane/ethene and propane/propene sepn. applications. This finding partly agrees with previous work based on the Ideal Adsorbed Soln. Theory.

An increase in demand for energy efficient processes for the sepn. of a mixt. of hydrocarbons drives the need for understanding metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) that can provide better noncryogenic alternatives for the fractionation of hydrocarbon mixts. Here we study the structure and properties of a metal-org. framework, Fe-MOF-74, and its effectiveness to sep. C1-C3 hydrocarbon mixts. The binding of these hydrocarbons to the open metal sites of Fe-MOF-74 has been investigated using a meta-generalized gradient approxn. d. functional, M06-L, which has previously been validated for systems contg. transition metals. For interpretive purposes, charge model 5 (CM5) is used to det. the partial at. charges on the metal cations and the oxygen atoms of the ligands surrounding these metal centers. Our computations show preferential binding to the metal center of Fe-MOF-74 of unsatd. hydrocarbons over satd. ones in agreement with exptl. results, and the calcd. binding energies are in semiquant. agreement with expt. The results are analyzed in terms of various factors contributing to the binding, including structural distortion, electrostatics, damped dispersion, charge transfer, back bonding, and ligand field effects on the d orbitals. The CM5 charges are not sensitive to small differences in structure.

The application of a metal-org. framework (MOF) has expanded into the area of heterogeneous catalysis, gas storage and sepn., drug delivery, and lightwt. magnets. Herein, we investigate the nature of olefin and paraffin binding on Fe/MOF-74 and identify several factors that det. sepn. efficiency using the first-principles calcns. The calcd. binding energies and magnetic orderings are in excellent agreement with those obsd. in expts. While the olefin strongly interacts with Fe atoms through a well-known π-complexation, the HOMO - 1(2) of the paraffin weakly interacts with Fe atoms without back-donation, facilitating the olefin-paraffin sepn. primarily. However, the mutual gas-gas interactions and magnetic transitions of the MOF host also contribute significantly to the total binding energy of each gas mol. as much as 2-28% and 6-8%, resp., emphasizing the necessity that these subtle effects must be handled carefully when considering selective binding with small energy differences. In particular, Fe/MOF-74 is shown to be a unique system where the guest-dependent magnetic transition obsd. only for the olefin adsorption is a secondary reason for the high olefin-paraffin adsorption selectivity measured. The understanding of the hydrocarbon binding energetics can provide a way to modify MOFs for enhanced sepn./sorption properties that can be complemented by principles of kinetic sepn.

Among various class of materials, metal-org. frameworks (MOF) are a most promising candidate for flue gas CO2 capture. In particular, M-MOF-74, where M = different metals, are equipped with open metal sites which can lead to very high CO2 uptake in post-combustion flue gas conditions. However, these structures are known to have poor CO2 capture performance under humid conditions since water mols. strongly bind to the unsatd. metal sites, out-competing CO2. This computational study used a pore space partition strategy via symmetry-matching regulated ligand insertion within the Mg-MOF-74 and Zn-MOF-74 structures to mitigate the water deterioration effect. For Zn-MOF-74, higher selectivity and larger CO2 uptake in binary mixt. conditions were obtained, demonstrating that redn. in MOF pore size is a viable strategy to capture CO2 under humid post-combustion conditions.

Recently, metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) with open iron sites (i.e., Fe0.1Mg1.9-MOF-74) have been shown to be promising material for catalyzing ethane to ethanol. In this computational study, various size-matching ligands are inserted into the Fe0.1Mg1.9-MOF-74 structure to further optimize this reaction. Our d. functional theory calcns. show that the presence of ligands enhances the binding affinity of the oxygen atoms of N2O to the iron atoms in the framework, thereby leading to an improvement in the oxidizing process. Furthermore, the reaction pathways for the new structures show reduced enthalpy barrier in the rate-detg. step in the oxidn. of ethane reaction cycle compared to the original Fe0.1Mg1.9-MOF-74. These findings provide ways in which the performance of the Fe0.1Mg1.9-MOF-74 can be optimized for next-generation catalysts.

Harvesting water from air is one of the key environmental related issues facing humanity in recent years. In this study, we demonstrate that the Ni-IRMOF74-III metal-org. framework structure attached with azopyridine mols. can potentially undergo photochem. induced cis/trans transition, leading to significant enhancement in the H2O working capacity. Specifically, grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations indicate an ultrahigh 0.20 kg kg-1 of H2O working capacity at 25°C adsorption and 65°C desorption conditions. More importantly, given that the cis/trans switching is predominantly responsible for the discrepancy in the H2O uptake, even in the mild condition of 35°C desorption (10°C diurnal temp. swing), the H2O working capacity is still very high at 0.18 kg kg-1. A review. QUANTUM ESPRESSO is an open-source distribution of computer codes for quantum-mech. materials modeling, based on d.-functional theory, pseudopotentials, and plane waves, and renowned for its performance on a wide range of hardware architectures, from laptops to massively parallel computers, as well as for the breadth of its applications. In this paper, we present a motivation and brief review of the ongoing effort to port QUANTUM ESPRESSO onto heterogeneous architectures based on hardware accelerators, which will overcome the energy constraints that are currently hindering the way toward exascale computing. Three parallel algorithms for classical mol. dynamics are presented. The first assigns each processor a fixed subset of atoms; the second assigns each a fixed subset of inter-at. forces to compute; the third assigns each a fixed spatial region. The algorithms are suitable for mol. dynamics models which can be difficult to parallelize efficiently - those with short-range forces where the neighbors of each atom change rapidly. They can be implemented on any distributed-memory parallel machine which allows for message-passing of data between independently executing processors. The algorithms are tested on a std. Lennard-Jones benchmark problem for system sizes ranging from 500 to 100,000,000 atoms on several parallel supercomputers - the nCUBE 2, Intel iPSC/860 and Paragon, and Cray T3D. Comparing the results to the fastest reported vectorized Cray Y-MP and C90 algorithm shows that the current generation of parallel machines is competitive with conventional vector supercomputers even for small problems. For large problems, the spatial algorithm achieves parallel efficiencies of 90% and a 1840-node Intel Paragon performs up to 165 faster than a single Cray C90 processor. Trade-offs between the three algorithms and guidelines for adapting them to more complex mol. dynamics simulations are also discussed.

Cryst. porous materials have a variety of uses, such as for catalysis and sepn. Identifying suitable materials for a given application can, in principle, be done by screening material databases. Such a screening requires automated high-throughput anal. tools that calc. structural properties for all materials contained in a database so they can be compared with search queries, grouped or classified. One important aspect of the structural anal. of materials such as zeolites and metal org. frameworks is the investigation of the geometrical parameters describing pores. Here, we present algorithms and tools to efficiently calc. some of these important parameters. Our tools are based on the Voronoi decompn., which for a given arrangement of atoms in a periodic domain provides a graph representation of the void space. The resulting Voronoi network is analyzed to obtain the diam. of the largest included sphere and the largest free sphere, which are two geometrical parameters that are frequently used to describe pore geometry. Accessibility of nodes in the network is also detd. for a given guest mol. and the resulting information is later used to retrieve dimensionality of channel systems as well as in Monte Carlo sampling of accessible surfaces and vols. The presented algorithms are implemented in a software tool, Zeo++, which includes a modified version of the Voro++ library. We present example applications of our algorithms and tools using zeolite frameworks currently listed in the Atlas of Zeolite Frameworks.

The main challenge for gas storage and sepn. in nanoporous materials is that many mols. of interest adsorb too weakly to be effectively retained. Instead of synthetically modifying the internal surface structure of the entire bulk-as is typically done to enhance adsorption-here we show that post exposure of a prototypical porous metal-org. framework to ethylenediamine can effectively retain a variety of weakly adsorbing mols. (for example, CO, CO2, SO2, C2H4, NO) inside the materials by forming a monolayer-thick cap at the external surface of microcrystals. Furthermore, this capping mechanism, based on hydrogen bonding as explained by ab initio modeling, opens the door for potential selectivity. For example, water mols. are shown to disrupt the hydrogen-bonded amine network and diffuse through the cap without hindrance and fully displace/release the retained small mols. out of the metal-org. framework at room temp. These findings may provide alternative strategies for gas storage, delivery and sepn.

A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are hybrid porous materials with many potential applications, which intimately depend on the presence of chem. functionality either at the org. linkers and/or at the metal nodes. Functionality that cannot be introduced into MOFs directly via de novo syntheses can be accessed through post-synthesis modification (PSM) on the reactive moieties of the linkers and/or nodes without disrupting the metal-linker bonds. Even more intriguing methods that go beyond PSM are herein termed building block replacement (BBR) which encompasses (i) solvent-assisted linker exchange (SALE), (ii) nonbridging ligand replacement, and (iii) transmetalation. These 1-step or tandem BBR processes involve exchanging key structural components of the MOF, which in turn should allow for the evolution of protoMOF structures (i.e., the use of a parent MOF as a template) to design MOFs composed of completely new components, presumably via single crystal to single crystal transformations. The influence of building block replacement on the stability and properties of MOFs are discussed, and some insights into their mechanistic aspects are provided. Future perspectives providing a glimpse into how these techniques can lead to various unexplored areas of MOF chem. are also presented.

A review. The efforts to implement pore space partition (PSP) in metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) and impact of PSP on gas uptake performance are reviewed. In the synthetic design of PSP, it is helpful to distinguish between factors that contribute to the framework formation and factors that serve the purpose of PSP. Because of the need for complementary structural roles, the synthesis of MOFs with PSP often involves multicomponent systems including mixed ligands, mixed inorg. nodes, or both. It is possible to accomplish both framework formation and PSP with a single type of polyfunctional ligands that use some functional groups (called framework-forming group) for framework formation and the remaining functional groups (called pore-partition group) for PSP. Alternatively, framework formation and PSP can be shouldered by different chem. species. For example, in a mixed-ligand system, one ligand (called framework-forming agent) can play the role of the framework formation while the other type of ligand (called pore-partition agent) can assume the role of PSP. PSP is sensitive to the types of inorg. secondary building units (SBUs). The coexistence of SBUs complementary in charge, connectivity, and so on can promote PSP. The use of heterometallic systems can promote the diversity of SBUs coexistent under a given condition. Heterometallic system with metal ions of different oxidn. states also provides the charge tunability of SBUs and the overall framework, providing an addnl. level of control in self-assembly and ultimately in the materials' properties. Of particular interest is the PSP in MIL-88 type (acs-type topol.) structure, which has led to a huge family of CPMs (called pacs CPMs, pacs = partitioned acs) exhibiting low isosteric heat of adsorption and yet superior CO2 uptake capacity.

Since its publication, the G. Horvath and K. Kawazoe (H-K) (1983) equation has been rapidly and widely adopted for calcg. the micropore size distribution from a single adsorption isotherm measured at a subcrit. temp. (e.g. N2 at 77 K or Ar at 87 K). In the H-K formulation, the ideal Henry's law (linearity) is assumed for the isotherm, even though the actual isotherms invariably follow the typical type I behavior, which is well represented by the Langmuir isotherm. The H-K formulation is modified by including the nonlinearity of the isotherm. Inclusion of nonlinearity results in sharpening of the pore size distribution and shifting of its peak position to a smaller size. Furthermore, the H-K equation is extended to spherical pores, and the improved H-K equation for spherical pores by including isotherm nonlinearity is also given. It is shown that the spherical-pore model is particularly useful for zeolites with cavities. Using the literature isotherm data, the improved H-K equations for three pore geometries (slit shape, cylinder and sphere) are compared with the original H-K equations. Clear improvements are seen in the calcd. micropore size distributions by using the improved H-K equations.

A review. In 2001, Mauri and Pickard introduced the gauge including projected augmented wave (GIPAW) method that enabled for the first time the calcn. of all-electron NMR parameters in solids, i.e. accounting for periodic boundary conditions. The GIPAW method roots in the plane wave pseudopotential formalism of the d. functional theory (DFT), and avoids the use of the cluster approxn. This method has undoubtedly revitalized the interest in quantum chem. calcns. in the solid-state NMR community. It has quickly evolved and improved so that the calcn. of the key components of NMR interactions, namely the shielding and elec. field gradient tensors, has now become a routine for most of the common nuclei studied in NMR. Availability of reliable implementations in several software packages (CASTEP, Quantum Espresso, PARATEC) make its usage more and more increasingly popular, maybe indispensable in near future for all material NMR studies. The majority of nuclei of the periodic table have already been investigated by GIPAW, and because of its high accuracy it is quickly becoming an essential tool for interpreting and understanding exptl. NMR spectra, providing reliable assignments of the obsd. resonances to crystallog. sites or enabling a priori prediction of NMR data. The continuous increase of computing power makes ever larger (and thus more realistic) systems amenable to first-principles anal. In the near future perspectives, as the incorporation of dynamical effects and/or disorder are still at their early developments, these areas will certainly be the prime target.

Zhao, Xiang; Bu, Xianhui; Zhai, Quan-Guo; Tran, Huy; Feng, Pingyun

Cryst. porous materials (CPMs) with superior CO2 uptake capacity have been prepd. using a ligand insertion pore space partition strategy. CPM-33b-Ni that contains no open metal sites exhibited the CO2 uptake capacity comparable to MOF-74 with the same metal (Ni) at 298 K and 1 bar.

Activation of metal-organic framework materials
Mondloch, Joseph E.; Karagiaridi, Olga; Farha, Omar K.; Hupp, Joseph T.

Royal Society of Chemistry

Cryst. metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as a highly desirable class of solid-state materials. Some of their most attractive features include exceptionally high porosities as well as surface areas. A key aspect to the realization of high porosity is the removal of guest mols. from the framework while still maintaining its structural integrity (i.e., "activation"). This contribution highlights the strategies utilized to date for activating MOFs, including: (i) conventional heating and vacuum; (ii) solvent-exchange; (iii) supercrit. CO2 (scCO2) exchange; (iv) freeze-drying; and (v) chem. treatment.
